challenges-to-voters-at-the-polling-plac.name: Challenges to Voters at the Polling Place

subtopics.fact: Only poll watchers may challenge voters on Election Day.
Challenges are allowed at the polls on Election Day.
subtopics.subtopic: What are the restrictions on polling place challenges?

subtopics.fact: On Election Day, a poll watcher may only challenge a person on the grounds that they are not the voter on the checklist or that the voter has already voted in the same election.
subtopics.subtopic: What are the allowed reasons on which a voter can be challenged?
Is there a requirement for the challenger to provide cause or evidence?

subtopics.fact: Election officials at the polling place will "informally hear the facts" and make a decision. If the election officials decide that the challenged voter cannot vote, the only way for the voter to continue the process is to get a court order guaranteeing their eligibility.
subtopics.subtopic: How does a voter defend their eligibility to vote if they are challenged?

subtopics.fact: Only first-time voters who did not register in person with a government official and did not provide ID with their registration form must show ID at the polling place.
subtopics.subtopic: Who must show ID to vote?

subtopics.fact: * A valid photo identification * A copy of a current utility bill * A copy of a current bank statement * A copy of a government check, paycheck, or any other government document that shows the current name and address of the voter
No. If a voter of whom ID is required does not present it, they may only vote a provisional ballot. The voter may have to take additional steps to get a provisional ballot to count.
subtopics.subtopic: If a voter has no ID, are there alternatives such as an oath or witness?
Is a student ID an acceptable form of identification?

subtopics.fact: If a voter presents a photo ID that contains an address (e.g., a driver's license), that ID is acceptable even if the address is not the address at which the voter is currently registered to vote. However, if the voter presents an ID without a photo (e.g., government document, utility bill, bank statement), that document must show the address at which the voter is registered to vote.
subtopics.subtopic: Does the address on the ID have to match the address at which the voter is registered?

subtopics.fact: No - the ID requirements are the same in all elections.
subtopics.subtopic: Do elections without federal offices on the ballot (such as off-year gubernatorial elections) have different ID requirements?
